title: Fundamentals of Linear Models 2025-2026: Workbook
text:
Welcome
This is the Workbook for the Statistics in Linguistics Course
This Workbook was designed as a companion to the Workgroup lectures and aims to provide you with basics of Statistical computing using the R language programming, an explanation of the exercises we will follow during the class as well as the assignments to be performed after the lecture.
Answers to the exercises will be included in the relevant Workgroup section after the due date of each of the assignments.
crumbs: Welcome

title: Introduction
text:
What would you learn in this course
This is a book created from markdown and executable code.
See Knuth (1984) for additional discussion of literate programming.
crumbs: Introduction

title: Introduction
text: Workbook organization
crumbs: Introduction

title: Introduction
text:
References for self study

Read Chapter 1, Introduction to R, from Bodo Winter‚Äôs book.
If you have never used R or any other programming language, read the following online basic tutorial, sections 2 to 8by UMC Utrecht: http://r-tutorial.nl/
Watch the following YouTube Videos on data frames by DataCamp: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9f2g7RN5N0I https://youtu.be/Nh6tSD4i4qs?feature=shared
Look at examples of dataframes usage in: https://bookdown.org/dli/rguide/working-with-data-frames.html





Knuth, Donald E. 1984. ‚ÄúLiterate Programming.‚Äù Comput. J. 27 (2): 97‚Äì111. https://doi.org/10.1093/comjnl/27.2.97.
crumbs: Introduction

title: Workgroup 1: Introduction to R and RStudio
text:
üß† Learning Objectives
In this session we will familiarize with the basics on the R computing language and the RStudio environment.
By the end of this lesson, you will be able to:
crumbs: Workgroup 1: Introduction to R and RStudio

title: Workgroup 1: Introduction to R and RStudio
text:
üõ†Ô∏è What is R?
R is a programming language designed for statistical computing and graphics. It is widely used among statisticians, data analysts, and researchers. To work with the programming language, the R interpreter needs to be installed. You can download it from the R homepage, which is:

http://cran.r-project.org/

There are versions available for Windows, Mac and Linux (several distributions). Select the current version (version 4.5.1 at the start of this course) and install it in your personal computer if you want to use it at home.
R installation includes a basic interface environment with a Console to enter commands and write scripts that can be launched using the R.exe or R.app.
crumbs: Workgroup 1: Introduction to R and RStudio

title: Workgroup 1: Introduction to R and RStudio
text: This interface is nonetheless quite limited and it is not normally used for data analysis and script development. You can use this language through lots of different applications and environments (e.g.¬†VSCode, JupyterLabs, etc..) . For this course we will introduce the most commonly use development environment for R: RStudio.
crumbs: Workgroup 1: Introduction to R and RStudio

title: Workgroup 1: Introduction to R and RStudio
text:
üíª What is RStudio?
RStudio is an Integrated Development Environment (IDE) for R, that makes coding in R and management of data analysis projects easier.
RStudio is a product developed by a company called posit, but that provides a free, open source RStudio Desktop version that can be downloaded here:

https://posit.co/download/rstudio-desktop/

As with R, there are versions available for Windows, Mac and several Linux distributions.
Once we launch RStudio, you can distinguish four different areas:

Console: Where R code is executed, you can type commands and see their output.
Source: Where you write and save scripts, Notebooks.
Environments: Includes tabs to inspect variables and inspect the command history as well as access tutorials.
Files/Plots/Packages/Help/Viewer: Includes tabs for file navigation, plotting, package management, and help.



RStudio Environment (extracted from RStudio User Guide)

We will familiarize with the interface during the exercises in the Workgroup sessions, but you can find a full description and information the following resources provided in the Posit website:

RStudio IDE User Guide
crumbs: Workgroup 1: Introduction to R and RStudio

title: Workgroup 1: Introduction to R and RStudio
section: üåêUsing R and RStudio on the web
text:
üåêUsing R and RStudio on the web
If you don‚Äôt want to install in your own computer, you can use the Posit Cloud environment. that provides a Cloud Free option. This is the approach we will use in this course, so that you can access your work from anywhere.
All assignments will be performed in Posit Cloud where I can follow your progress and assist in case of issues.

üìù Exercise1: Connect to Posit Cloud {#sec-üìù-exercise1}
In order to use Posit Cloud you need to register for this course following the link below.
https://posit.cloud/spaces/681791/join?access_code=Da9RyPvqyx7Jymq_aHZpKYwBuJJ-45h5bjS1Y7tq
You will be directed to the following page. Select the sign-up option and create your account.


Posit Cloud Sign-in page

Once you sign-in you should see the course project as in the image below:




Open it and explore the RStudio interface.
crumbs: Workgroup 1: Introduction to R and RStudio

title: Workgroup 1: Introduction to R and RStudio
text:
Commands and operators
R
>
That‚Äôs the command prompt. When you see this, it means that R is waiting patiently for you to do something!
One of the easiest things you can do with R is use it as a simple calculator, so it‚Äôs a good place to start. For instance, try typing 10 + 20, and hitting enter.1 When you do this, you‚Äôve entered a command, and R will ‚Äúexecute‚Äù that command. What you see on screen now will be this:
> 10 + 20
[1] 30
Not a lot of surprises in this extract. But there‚Äôs a few things worth talking about, even with such a simple example. Firstly, it‚Äôs important that you understand how to read the extract. In this example, what I typed was the 10 + 20 part. I didn‚Äôt type the > symbol: that‚Äôs just the R command prompt and isn‚Äôt part of the actual command. And neither did I type the [1] 30 part. That‚Äôs what R printed out in response to my command.
Secondly, it‚Äôs important to understand how the output is formatted. Obviously, the correct answer to the sum 10 + 20 is 30, and not surprisingly R has printed that out as part of its response. But it‚Äôs also printed out this [1] part, which probably doesn‚Äôt make a lot of sense to you right now. You‚Äôre going to see that a lot. I‚Äôll talk about what this means in a bit more detail later on, but for now you can think of [1] 30 as if R were saying ‚Äúthe answer to the 1st question you asked is 30‚Äù. That‚Äôs not quite the truth, but it‚Äôs close enough for now. And in any case it‚Äôs not really very interesting at the moment: we only asked R to calculate one thing, so obviously there‚Äôs only one answer printed on the screen. Later on this will change, and the [1] part will start to make a bit more sense. For now, I just don‚Äôt want you to get confused or concerned by it.
crumbs: Workgroup 1: Introduction to R and RStudio

title: Workgroup 1: Introduction to R and RStudio
text:
Variables
# This is a comment 
x <- 5       # Assign 5 to variable x 
y <- 10      # Assign 10 to variable y 
z <- x + y   # Add x and y 
print(z)     # Print the result

Open RStudio and type the following in the console:

Add 15 and 27
Multiply 6 by 9
Divide 100 by 4

title: Workgroup 1: Introduction to R and RStudio
text:
2. Create Variables
a <- 12 
b <- 8 
c <- a * b 
print(c) 
Try changing the values of a and b and re-run the code.
crumbs: Workgroup 1: Introduction to R and RStudio

title: Workgroup 1: Introduction to R and RStudio
text:
3. Create a dataframe
Create a dataframe coming up with a sample data of your own (possibly made up) including 4 columns and 6 rows: one column with a factor with two levels, another column with a factor with 3 levels and two columns with numeric values.
You can create a dataframe in several ways, but below you see an example on the steps to create a dataframe based on on vectors.
Create individual variables with vectors including the values

NounAnimacy<-c("animate","inanimate","inanimate","animate","animate","animate")
NounAnimacy

[1] "animate"   "inanimate" "inanimate" "animate"   "animate"   "animate"  


NounGender<-c("feminine","masculine","neuter","masculine","feminine","feminine")
NounGender

NounGender<-c("feminine","masculine","neuter","masculine","feminine","feminine")
NounGender

[1] "feminine"  "masculine" "neuter"    "masculine" "feminine"  "feminine" 



NounLength<-c(6,7,4,5,8,6)
NounLength

[1] 6 7 4 5 8 6

NounFrequency<-c(638,799,390,569,567,665)
NounFrequency

[1] 638 799 390 569 567 665


As you can see from the output above, data in the variables NounAnimacy and NounGender are considered as words, or literal strings. The next step is to indicate they are factors.

NounAnimacy<-as.factor(NounAnimacy)
NounAnimacy

[1] animate   inanimate inanimate animate   animate   animate  
Levels: animate inanimate

NounGender<-as.factor(NounGender)
NounGender

[1] feminine  masculine neuter    masculine feminine  feminine 
Levels: feminine masculine neuter


As you can see by the output produced, now the variables are considered as factors, and Levels indicate the unique values that the predictor takes.
With the variables above, we can now create a dataframe.

Dataexample<-data.frame(NounAnimacy,NounGender,NounLength,NounFrequency)
Dataexample

  NounAnimacy NounGender NounLength NounFrequency
1     animate   feminine          6           638
2   inanimate  masculine          7           799
3   inanimate     neuter          4           390
4     animate  masculine          5           569
5     animate   feminine          8           567
6     animate   feminine          6           665
crumbs: Workgroup 1: Introduction to R and RStudio

title: Workgroup 1: Introduction to R and RStudio
text:
Reading material


Basics on R programming:

Chapter 1, Introduction to R, from Bodo Winter‚Äôs book.
Sections 2 to 8 on R basic Tutorial by UMC Utrecht



A good starters reference for R is the book ‚ÄúR for Data Science‚Äù (Wickham, H., √áetinkaya-Rundel, M., & Grolemund, G. (2023). R for data science. ‚Äù O‚ÄôReilly Media, Inc.‚Äù.). The book is available online freely at:
-   [Hands On Programming with R](https://rstudio-education.github.io/hopr/)

-   [R for Data Science](https://r4ds.hadley.nz/)

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9f2g7RN5N0I

title: Workgroup 1: Introduction to R and RStudio
text: Seriously. If you‚Äôre in a position to do so, open up R and start typing. The simple act of typing it rather than ‚Äújust reading‚Äù makes a big difference. It makes the concepts more concrete, and it ties the abstract ideas (programming and statistics) to the actual context in which you need to use them. Statistics is something you do, not just something you read about in a textbook.‚Ü©Ô∏é
crumbs: Workgroup 1: Introduction to R and RStudio

title: 1¬† Introduction to the R language
text: 2 ‚úçÔ∏è R Syntax

1¬† Introduction to the R language

title: 1¬† Introduction to the R language
text:
2.1 Commands and operators
R
>
That‚Äôs the command prompt. When you see this, it means that R is waiting patiently for you to do something!
One of the easiest things you can do with R is use it as a simple calculator, so it‚Äôs a good place to start. For instance, try typing 10 + 20, and hitting enter.1 When you do this, you‚Äôve entered a command, and R will ‚Äúexecute‚Äù that command. What you see on screen now will be this:
> 10 + 20
[1] 30
Not a lot of surprises in this extract. But there‚Äôs a few things worth talking about, even with such a simple example. Firstly, it‚Äôs important that you understand how to read the extract. In this example, what I typed was the 10 + 20 part. I didn‚Äôt type the > symbol: that‚Äôs just the R command prompt and isn‚Äôt part of the actual command. And neither did I type the [1] 30 part. That‚Äôs what R printed out in response to my command.
Secondly, it‚Äôs important to understand how the output is formatted. Obviously, the correct answer to the sum 10 + 20 is 30, and not surprisingly R has printed that out as part of its response. But it‚Äôs also printed out this [1] part, which probably doesn‚Äôt make a lot of sense to you right now. You‚Äôre going to see that a lot. I‚Äôll talk about what this means in a bit more detail later on, but for now you can think of [1] 30 as if R were saying ‚Äúthe answer to the 1st question you asked is 30‚Äù. That‚Äôs not quite the truth, but it‚Äôs close enough for now. And in any case it‚Äôs not really very interesting at the moment: we only asked R to calculate one thing, so obviously there‚Äôs only one answer printed on the screen. Later on this will change, and the [1] part will start to make a bit more sense. For now, I just don‚Äôt want you to get confused or concerned by it.
crumbs: Workgroup 1: Introduction to R and RStudio
1¬† Introduction to the R language

title: 1¬† Introduction to the R language
text:
2.2 Variables
# This is a comment 
x <- 5       # Assign 5 to variable x 
y <- 10      # Assign 10 to variable y 
z <- x + y   # Add x and y 
print(z)     # Print the result
crumbs: Workgroup 1: Introduction to R and RStudio
1¬† Introduction to the R language

title: 1¬† Introduction to the R language
text:
2.3 Functions
Functions perform tasks in R. They take in inputs called arguments and return outputs. You can either manually specify a function‚Äôs arguments or use the function‚Äôs default values.

For example, the function seq() in R generates a sequence of numbers. If you just run seq() it will return the value 1. That doesn‚Äôt seem very useful! This is because the default arguments are set as seq(from = 1, to = 1). Thus, if you don‚Äôt pass in different values for from and to to change this behavior, R just assumes all you want is the number 1. You can change the argument values by updating the values after the = sign. If we try out seq(from = 2, to = 5) we get the result 2 3 4 5 that we might expect.
We‚Äôll work with functions a lot throughout this book and you‚Äôll get lots of practice in understanding their behaviors. To further assist you in understanding when a function is mentioned in the book, we‚Äôll also include the () after them as we did with seq() above.
crumbs: Workgroup 1: Introduction to R and RStudio
1¬† Introduction to the R language

title: 1¬† Introduction to the R language
text: 2.4 Loops and conditional statements
crumbs: Workgroup 1: Introduction to R and RStudio
1¬† Introduction to the R language

title: 1¬† Introduction to the R language
text:
2.5 Data types

2.5.1 Basic types

2.5.2 Vectors and lists
Vectors are a groups of values built using the combine function,¬†c().
For example,¬†c(6, 11, 13, 31, 90, 92)¬†creates a six element series of positive integer values

2.5.3 Dataframes and tibbles
Dataframes can be thought of as sets of data organized in a spreadsheet format in rows and columns.
crumbs: Workgroup 1: Introduction to R and RStudio
1¬† Introduction to the R language

You can create a dataframe in several ways, but below you see an example on the steps to create a dataframe based on on vectors.
Create individual variables with vectors including the values

NounAnimacy<-c("animate","inanimate","inanimate","animate","animate","animate")

[1] "animate"   "inanimate" "inanimate" "animate"   "animate"   "animate"

[1] 6 7 4 5 8 6

NounFrequency<-c(638,799,390,569,567,665)

[1] 638 799 390 569 567 665


As you can see from the output above, data in the variables NounAnimacy and NounGender are considered as words, or literal strings. The next step is to indicate they are factors.

NounAnimacy<-as.factor(NounAnimacy)
NounAnimacy

[1] animate   inanimate inanimate animate   animate   animate  
Levels: animate inanimate

NounGender<-as.factor(NounGender)
NounGender

[1] feminine  masculine neuter    masculine feminine  feminine 
Levels: feminine masculine neuter


As you can see by the output produced, now the variables are considered as factors, and Levels indicate the unique values that the predictor takes.
With the variables above, we can now create a dataframe.

Dataexample<-data.frame(NounAnimacy,NounGender,NounLength,NounFrequency)
Dataexample

  NounAnimacy NounGender NounLength NounFrequency
1     animate   feminine          6           638
2   inanimate  masculine          7           799

title: 4¬† Using Notebooks and R Markdown
text:
4.1 Quarto
Quarto enables you to weave together content and executable code into a finished document. To learn more about Quarto see https://quarto.org.
crumbs: Workgroup 1: Introduction to R and RStudio
4¬† Using Notebooks and R Markdown

title: 4¬† Using Notebooks and R Markdown
text:
4.2 Running Code
When you click the Render button a document will be generated that includes both content and the output of embedded code. You can embed code like this:

1 + 1

[1] 2


You can add options to executable code like this


[1] 4


The echo: false option disables the printing of code (only output is displayed).
crumbs: Workgroup 1: Introduction to R and RStudio
4¬† Using Notebooks and R Markdown

title: Workgroup 2: Data Exploration with R
text:
Explore a Built-in Dataset
-Load the library called languageR, using the following command . In the languageR library, there are some sample datasets that we will use for future workgroups.

# load required libraries
library(languageR)
library(tidyverse)

Warning: package 'ggplot2' was built under R version 4.4.3


‚îÄ‚îÄ Attaching core tidyverse packages ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ tidyverse 2.0.0 ‚îÄ‚îÄ
‚úî dplyr     1.1.4     ‚úî readr     2.1.5
‚úî forcats   1.0.0     ‚úî stringr   1.5.1
‚úî ggplot2   3.5.2     ‚úî tibble    3.2.1
‚úî lubridate 1.9.3     ‚úî tidyr     1.3.1
‚úî purrr     1.0.2     
‚îÄ‚îÄ Conflicts ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ‚îÄ tidyverse_conflicts() ‚îÄ‚îÄ
‚úñ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
‚úñ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
‚Ñπ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


From the languageR library we will use a sample dataframe called spanishMeta. This dataset is based on a more general dataset called spanish also included in the library, from Spassova, M. S. (2006) Las marcas sintacticas de atribucion forense de autoria de textos escritos en espanol, Masters thesis, Institut Universitari de Linguistica Aplicada, Universitat Pompeu Fabra, Barcelona
Display dataframe
To view the contents of a dataset we can simply write the name of the dataset in the console

  spanishMeta

   Author YearOfBirth  TextName PubDate Nwords    FullName
1       C        1916 X14458gll    1983   2972        Cela
2       C        1916 X14459gll    1951   3040        Cela
3       C        1916 X14460gll    1956   3066        Cela
4       C        1916 X14461gll    1948   3044        Cela
5       C        1916 X14462gll    1942   3053        Cela
6       M        1943 X14463gll    1986   3013     Mendoza
7       M        1943 X14464gll    1992   3049     Mendoza
8       M        1943 X14465gll    1989   3042     Mendoza
9       M        1943 X14466gll    1982   3039     Mendoza
10      M        1943 X14467gll    2002   3045     Mendoza
11      V        1936 X14472gll    1965   3037 VargasLLosa
12      V        1936 X14473gll    1963   3067 VargasLLosa
13      V        1936 X14474gll    1977   3020 VargasLLosa
14      V        1936 X14475gll    1987   3016 VargasLLosa
15      V        1936 X14476gll    1981   3054 VargasLLosa


If we have a lot of data, the console display will be very long. Then you can use the head() function to only see the first few rows of the dataset

head(spanishMeta)

  Author YearOfBirth  TextName PubDate Nwords FullName
1      C        1916 X14458gll    1983   2972     Cela
2      C        1916 X14459gll    1951   3040     Cela
3      C        1916 X14460gll    1956   3066     Cela
4      C        1916 X14461gll    1948   3044     Cela
5      C        1916 X14462gll    1942   3053     Cela
6      M        1943 X14463gll    1986   3013  Mendoza


By default the function shows the first 6 rows of the dataset. if you look at the options of the function using help(head), you can see that there is a parameter (called argument in the vocabulary of R) n that can be used to indicate the number of rows to show. For the exercise, to show 4 rows, you can use:

head(spanishMeta, n=4)

  Author YearOfBirth  TextName PubDate Nwords FullName
1      C        1916 X14458gll    1983   2972     Cela
2      C        1916 X14459gll    1951   3040     Cela
3      C        1916 X14460gll    1956   3066     Cela
4      C        1916 X14461gll    1948   3044     Cela


Extract column names
There a number of functions that allow to inspect data sets: * str(): provides a brief description of the data set variables and contents * names(): lists the names of the variables * summary(): gives basic summary statistics for every variable (we will explore this in the next assignment) * head(): shows the first rows of the dataset (as we saw above) * tail(): shows the last rows of the dataset
In the assignment it was asked to list the names of the variables in the dataset. The easiest way is to use the names() function

names(spanishMeta)

[1] "Author"      "YearOfBirth" "TextName"    "PubDate"     "Nwords"     
[6] "FullName"   


Extract vector
Accessing the variables of a dataset is possible using the $ operator. So for example, to list the contents of the PubDate

spanishMeta$PubDate

 [1] 1983 1951 1956 1948 1942 1986 1992 1989 1982 2002 1965 1963 1977 1987 1981


In the exercise it was asked to take this information and include it in a variable called PublicationDate. Using the above notation this is simply done as

PublicationDate<-spanishMeta$PubDate 
PublicationDate

 [1] 1983 1951 1956 1948 1942 1986 1992 1989 1982 2002 1965 1963 1977 1987 1981


Sort a vector
You can sort the vector using the sort() function as below.

sort(PublicationDate)

 [1] 1942 1948 1951 1956 1963 1965 1977 1981 1982 1983 1986 1987 1989 1992 2002



sort(PublicationDate,decreasing = TRUE)

 [1] 2002 1992 1989 1987 1986 1983 1982 1981 1977 1965 1963 1956 1951 1948 1942


Finally, there are many functions available to work, modify, and access dataframes. As an example let‚Äôs see how we could select a part of the dataframe based on a criteria. If we want to select the entries that were published before 1980 for example, we can do the following

spanishMeta[spanishMeta$PubDate<1980,]

   Author YearOfBirth  TextName PubDate Nwords    FullName
2       C        1916 X14459gll    1951   3040        Cela
3       C        1916 X14460gll    1956   3066        Cela
4       C        1916 X14461gll    1948   3044        Cela
5       C        1916 X14462gll    1942   3053        Cela
11      V        1936 X14472gll    1965   3037 VargasLLosa
12      V        1936 X14473gll    1963   3067 VargasLLosa
13      V        1936 X14474gll    1977   3020 VargasLLosa


You can also use the subset() function to make a selection

subset(spanishMeta, PubDate<1980)

   Author YearOfBirth  TextName PubDate Nwords    FullName
2       C        1916 X14459gll    1951   3040        Cela
3       C        1916 X14460gll    1956   3066        Cela
4       C        1916 X14461gll    1948   3044        Cela
5       C        1916 X14462gll    1942   3053        Cela
11      V        1936 X14472gll    1965   3037 VargasLLosa
12      V        1936 X14473gll    1963   3067 VargasLLosa
13      V        1936 X14474gll    1977   3020 VargasLLosa


For all the operations above you can also use pipes:

library(dplyr)


PublicationDate %>% sort

 [1] 1942 1948 1951 1956 1963 1965 1977 1981 1982 1983 1986 1987 1989 1992 2002



PublicationDate %>% sort(decreasing = TRUE)

 [1] 2002 1992 1989 1987 1986 1983 1982 1981 1977 1965 1963 1956 1951 1948 1942



spanishMeta %>% filter(PubDate<1980)

   Author YearOfBirth  TextName PubDate Nwords    FullName
2       C        1916 X14459gll    1951   3040        Cela
3       C        1916 X14460gll    1956   3066        Cela
4       C        1916 X14461gll    1948   3044        Cela
5       C        1916 X14462gll    1942   3053        Cela
11      V        1936 X14472gll    1965   3037 VargasLLosa
12      V        1936 X14473gll    1963   3067 VargasLLosa
13      V        1936 X14474gll    1977   3020 VargasLLosa


For self-study and exploration look at this website to get information on basic manipulation of dataframes.

Quarto enables you to weave together content and executable code into a finished document. To learn more about Quarto see https://quarto.org.

title: 6¬† Data Organization and Transformation
text:
6.2 Running Code
When you click the Render button a document will be generated that includes both content and the output of embedded code. You can embed code like this:

1 + 1

[1] 2


You can add options to executable code like this


[1] 4


The echo: false option disables the printing of code (only output is displayed).

crumbs: Workgroup 3: Data exploration with R (II)

title: Workgroup 3: Data exploration with R (II)
text:
Basic Plotting

Note on ggplot2: The intention of this example was to show the power of ggplot2 to produce graphs of all types. It is beyond the scope of this course to learn how to use it and you are not expected to know it for the exams. For the interested readers there are several books and resources on the topic:


R Graphics Cookbook by Winston Chang
ggplot2: Elegant Graphics for Data Analysis by Hadley Wickham
